Award.AwardTitle: Group Travel Grant for the Doctoral Consortium of the IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant partially supports the participation of 20 students from US institutions in the Doctoral Consortium at the IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR) 2015. CVPR is the premier annual conference in computer vision with about 2000 senior, junior and student participants. It is held in North America and attended by members of the international research community. The goal of the Doctoral Consortium is to highlight the work of senior PhD students who are within six months of receiving their degrees (including recent graduates), and to give these students an opportunity to discuss their research and career options with faculty and researchers who have relevant expertise. NSF support covers some of the costs for selected US graduate students to attend the conference.

The intellectual merit of this project rests in the selection of top-quality PhD students whose research is showcased and to whom feedback is provided by senior researchers. The opportunity to receive advice on their research work and career plans from experts from different institutions, and with potentially different perspectives, is often not available internally at one's own institution. The broader impacts of this project include supporting the career development of some of the brightest junior researchers in computer vision, contributing to the research community in general by drawing attention to an important aspect of graduate student development, potentially increasing the number of active researchers and educators in STEM, and ensuring that the computer vision community, through its recent graduates, makes fast advances in solving problems that will benefit society as a whole. The Doctoral Consortium aims to have representation from a diverse group of participants in terms of gender, ethnic background, academic institution, and geographic location.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to provide mentorship to senior PhD students in computer vision, and increase their visibility in the research community. This mentorship took place at the Doctoral Consortium event held in conjunction with the 2015 IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR). The award for this project provided partial travel support for 15 students at US universities.

The mentorship by established senior researchers, and the networking opportunities that the event provides, are not available at one's own institution. The event benefits both the young researchers, and the computer vision community as a whole by helping these young researchers achieve their full potential and apply their skills in the most appropriate career path. It also benefits society through the potential high-impact computer vision applications that these researchers create.

Graduate student participants submitted applications highlighting their research and publications. Admitted applicants were matched with mentors for which they expressed preference. The list of mentors included both faculty and industry researchers. During the Doctoral Consortium event, held during lunch on the second main conference day, the participants presented their work to their mentors in poster format, then discussed career opportunities with their mentors. The student participants' names were provided in the conference program and online, thus increasing their visibility further to both other researchers and potential employers.

The participants' feedback on the event was largely very positive. Participants thought that the event was particularly useful in terms of advice for choosing between an academic and industry career, networking opportunities, and financial support to attend the conference. The feedback received from participants is being incorporated in the next Doctoral Consortium, to be held at CVPR 2016, chaired by the PI. The Doctoral Consortium event is now a regular component of CVPR, and was also included in the program of the 2015 International Conference on Computer Vision (ICCV).
